comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>This is obviously extremely late. It slipped my mind until now, but I wanted to share my answer to this question, but have been quite busy. I actually saved this question for last (except "Question" 7) when I did the homework. I wanted to save it for last because it's not only by far the easiest (lol) but also it was fundamentally an interesting question to answer. I thought I would summarize and elaborate on my written answers for this question here.</paragraph><paragraph>(a) I would like to gain mathematical and coding maturity I can apply to my academic research in economics and philosophy as well as startup work. I'm also interested in the possibility of AGI.</paragraph><paragraph>(b) I'm pretty familiar with standard AI concerns regrading bias or privacy, but I got GPT to say some pretty interesting stuff. It said that GenAI "lowers" the barrier to entry for mediocre work in general, forcing researchers and startup founders to perform at a higher level in order to stand out from the crowd. I have actually come across this myself. As an academic researcher, I've noticed how increasingly common it is for one to see deep learning being applied to economics. While some of this (i.e. Susan Athey or John Horton's work) is high-quality, sometimes GenAI is used to write bulky sections of academic papers, both in economics and in adjacent fields (even machine learning research itself), although this research is less likely to be published. I'm also taking a Cognitive Science accelerator course for startups and they point out that with the advent of so many AI platforms making "vibe coding" and non-technical construction of platforms so much easier, founders have to be a lot more creative when it comes to standing out to investors. Anyway, this is a "meta-lesson" I feel is important for people to take away from this course, beyond all the technical details we are going to learn.</paragraph><paragraph>(c) I found Donoho's paper to be a very interesting perspective, in that data, reproducibility, and a competitive research culture are all necessary to fully capitalize on the power of data in the modern world. Reading Donoho made me realize that frictionless reproducibility and open research exchanges aren’t just technical conveniences, they reshape how fast whole fields evolve, which pushes me to think about aligning my own work in economics, philosophy, and energy with these practices so that my contributions can spread, compound, and actually matter in a competitive research culture. This also brings to mind something my machine learning graduate student childhood friend pointed out: apparently today a lot of machine learning research is extremely low-quality, and sometimes difficult or even impossible to replicate, partially due to bad field practices that are considered common at a lot of places, such as reverse-engineering theoretical justifications after results and plucking out particularly good individual values out of a see of mediocre values when testing a model. Now, I don't know as much as he does, so maybe this isn't entirely accurate. However, if this practice infects top research labs (which thankfully I doubt), that of course would seriously stall science in any field, and is something to keep in mind.</paragraph><paragraph>(d) Mainly a few things (a) overview of state of the art research would be nice (b) more undergrad autonomy on the final project would be cool due to my specific interests (why aren't undergrads allowed to lead projects?) (c) ofc I would enjoy seeing specific applications to economics and philosophy or energy prediction systems (d) practice material for the final would be quite useful.<break/><break/>Also, ChatGPT wrote exactly one of my sentences in the above answer. If anyone ever has too much time on their hands, feel free to try and find it.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
This is obviously extremely late. It slipped my mind until now, but I wanted to share my answer to this question, but have been quite busy. I actually saved this question for last (except "Question" 7) when I did the homework. I wanted to save it for last because it's not only by far the easiest (lol) but also it was fundamentally an interesting question to answer. I thought I would summarize and elaborate on my written answers for this question here.

(a) I would like to gain mathematical and coding maturity I can apply to my academic research in economics and philosophy as well as startup work. I'm also interested in the possibility of AGI.

(b) I'm pretty familiar with standard AI concerns regrading bias or privacy, but I got GPT to say some pretty interesting stuff. It said that GenAI "lowers" the barrier to entry for mediocre work in general, forcing researchers and startup founders to perform at a higher level in order to stand out from the crowd. I have actually come across this myself. As an academic researcher, I've noticed how increasingly common it is for one to see deep learning being applied to economics. While some of this (i.e. Susan Athey or John Horton's work) is high-quality, sometimes GenAI is used to write bulky sections of academic papers, both in economics and in adjacent fields (even machine learning research itself), although this research is less likely to be published. I'm also taking a Cognitive Science accelerator course for startups and they point out that with the advent of so many AI platforms making "vibe coding" and non-technical construction of platforms so much easier, founders have to be a lot more creative when it comes to standing out to investors. Anyway, this is a "meta-lesson" I feel is important for people to take away from this course, beyond all the technical details we are going to learn.

(c) I found Donoho's paper to be a very interesting perspective, in that data, reproducibility, and a competitive research culture are all necessary to fully capitalize on the power of data in the modern world. Reading Donoho made me realize that frictionless reproducibility and open research exchanges aren’t just technical conveniences, they reshape how fast whole fields evolve, which pushes me to think about aligning my own work in economics, philosophy, and energy with these practices so that my contributions can spread, compound, and actually matter in a competitive research culture. This also brings to mind something my machine learning graduate student childhood friend pointed out: apparently today a lot of machine learning research is extremely low-quality, and sometimes difficult or even impossible to replicate, partially due to bad field practices that are considered common at a lot of places, such as reverse-engineering theoretical justifications after results and plucking out particularly good individual values out of a see of mediocre values when testing a model. Now, I don't know as much as he does, so maybe this isn't entirely accurate. However, if this practice infects top research labs (which thankfully I doubt), that of course would seriously stall science in any field, and is something to keep in mind.

(d) Mainly a few things (a) overview of state of the art research would be nice (b) more undergrad autonomy on the final project would be cool due to my specific interests (why aren't undergrads allowed to lead projects?) (c) ofc I would enjoy seeing specific applications to economics and philosophy or energy prediction systems (d) practice material for the final would be quite useful.

Also, ChatGPT wrote exactly one of my sentences in the above answer. If anyone ever has too much time on their hands, feel free to try and find it.
